content: Traditional Hainanese sweet dumpling **Yi bua** ([Chinese](/wiki/Chinese_language): 薏粑; [pinyin](/wiki/Pinyin): *yìbā*, also spelt **yi buak**, **yi buah**, or **yibua**) is a traditional [Hainanese](/wiki/Hainan_cuisine) [kuih](/wiki/Kuih). It is a Hainanese steamed dumpling made of glutinous rice flour dough. Also known as *kuih e-oua*, it is filled with a [palm sugar](/wiki/Palm_sugar) sweetened mixture of grated [coconut](/wiki/Coconut), toasted [sesame seeds](/wiki/Sesame_seed) and crushed roasted [peanuts](/wiki/Peanut), wrapped with sheets of banana leaves pressed into a fluted cup shape, and customarily marked with a dab of red food colouring. This kuih is traditionally served during a wedding and a baby's full-moon celebration. - Food portal - China portal - [Kue](/wiki/Kue) - [Kuih](/wiki/Kuih) - [List of steamed foods](/wiki/List_of_steamed_foods) - [Mochi](/wiki/Mochi)
title: Yi bua
